title: A passenger aircraft that flies around the world at Mach 9? Sure, why not
summary: “How much does the world change if you can get anywhere in an hour?”

title: Japan delays H2A launch in the wake of H3 failure
summary: Japan has delayed the launch of a H-2A rocket planned for May to no earlier than August in the wake of the failed inaugural flight of H3 rocket.

title: China’s Space Pioneer reaches orbit with liquid propellent rocket
summary: Space Pioneer has become the first Chinese private launch firm to achieve orbit with a liquid propellant rocket.

title: China’s Space Pioneer reaches orbit with liquid propellant rocket
summary: Space Pioneer has become the first Chinese private launch firm to achieve orbit with a liquid propellant rocket.

title: NASA policy discourages naming missions after individuals
summary: A new NASA policy makes it unlikely future missions will be named after individuals in response to the controversy surrounding the naming of the James Webb Space Telescope.

title: SpaceX launches 10 satellites for U.S. Space Development Agency
summary: A SpaceX Falcon 9 rocket lifted off April 2 at 10:29 a.m. Eastern from Launch Complex 4 East at Vandenberg Space Force Base, California, carrying 10 military satellites for the U.S. Space Development Agency.

title: SpaceX launches initial satellites for Space Development Agency
summary: SpaceX has launched a batch of 10 communications and missile tracking satellites on the Tranche 0 Flight 1 mission for the Space Development Agency (SDA) on Sunday, April 2, 2023, at 7:29 AM PDT (14:29 UTC).

title: ISRO Successfully Conducts RLV Autonomous Landing Mission
summary: The Indian Space Research Organisation (ISRO) has successfully conducted their Reusable Launch Vehicle Autonomous Landing Mission (RLV LEX).

title: SpaceX moves Starship to launch site, and liftoff could be just days away
summary: No fooling—Starship rolled back to the launch pad on April 1.

title: EGS Integration Console engineers review Artemis I campaign
summary: The NASA Exploration Ground Systems (EGS) program is continuing to review the experiences from the Artemis I launch campaign as teams plan and prepare for Artemis II in a couple of years. History suggested there would be a long ground campaign to the Space Launch System’s (SLS) first liftoff, and a series of issues — primarily with fueling the SLS Core Stage — kept Artemis I on the ground through most of 2022.
